text: It's also pretty clear that some ppl can't handle a f@g being such an influential writer.

Ironically, I've been on "Foucault strike" for several years. I don't teach him. Can rely on New School colleagues to do that. I think some of his concepts became doxa thru over use. I just hate to see him get attacked for petty factional reasons.
Bogdanov once said that the working class, not Marx, wrote Capital. Marx was their secretary. Puts it a provocatively, but I like that.

Rather: how do social movements think? How does collective praxis crystalize into concepts? How does authorship and the archive reify collective praxis into "ideas" as if they had an autonomous or even determinative history?

To be clear: I don't think, as far as a method of reading goes, that this is about putting thinkers in context. That still treats the thinker and the context as separate. It's still an idealist "history of ideas." There is no such thing as a Marxist "history of ideas."
So much of soc dem praxis reminds me of Trotskyists: everything is either an object of recruitment to the master project they alone possess or to be opposed as a distraction from it.

There's a lot to be learned from Foucault's critique of Sartre as the 'general intellectual,' with a grand theory of everything. F's category of the 'specific intellectual' pointed to a different practice. One u can use also against the later Foucault, tbh.
The way 'neoliberal' is used, as a mood rather than a concept, so reminds me of the use of 'alienation' in the 70s. Hand-waving at what is distasteful. The petit bourgeois mentality in a gesture.
Typical of the petit bourgeois strand of soc dem thinking to imagine that you undermine a liberation movement by attacking its ideas, its thinker.

â€”and there were Marxists engaged in the selective erasure of that history (looking at you New Left Review). Political self-education can begin with the critique of the reading list you're handed. There's more silences in it than the ones we know.
It is generally the case tho that if you studied modern 'thought' without attending to how all of it connects to the history of communism, you probably don't know the half of it.
Foucault emerged out of a context in which communist thought hung on institutionally, but was popularized in one in which it was rooted out.
Has to be said tho: the prevalence of Foucault in American grad schools is an indirect result of the black listing of communist intellectuals in the 50s. He filled a void still there decades later.
It's because the police and prisons are a material form that certain social democrats think like cops. They did not come up with those 'ideas' all on their own.

Here the Foucault of 'Discipline and Punish' can be a useful foil against both the later reception of Foucault and the idealist turn in Marxist historical thinking. Material form determines consciousness, not the other way around.

Altho if you're doing 'history of ideas,' pls remember that 'neoliberal' is a term super-imposed from our time, not organic to this history. Marxists had not yet become idealists talking about 'neoliberalism' at that time. They still thought like Marxists.

In most contexts I highlight the positive effects of communist intellectual work because the Cold War has erased it. But here, the thing to stress is the space to its left that Foucault created. This is a directly political history, not a 'history of ideas' thing.

He had to create an entire worldview to be able to exist independently of it. Not that you'd know any of this reading American opinionators who just read some texts in American grad school, as if that was the institutional form in which the texts themselves emerged.

It's ironic, because the context in which Foucault worked was one in which it was very, very hard to be a left-wing intellectual outside the orbit of the communist party (from which he broke pretty early on).
And to me that's still more interesting than the 'History of Sexuality' or the later lectures on biopolitics. But there's more than one Foucault.

There's several eras to Foucault's work. 'Discipline and Punish' and 'Birth of the Clinic' is just one moment in it. I see it as descending from Bachelard and Canguillem's work on philosophy of science, but extended to the social sciences and their material effects.

At the time, most Marxists could only think one institutional site of struggle, and that was 'factory.' After Foucault, one could engage with 'prison' or 'psychiatric ward' and 'school' as having their own materiality, not just as adjuncts or doubles of 'factory.'

I was handed home-made translations of Foucault in the late 70s by gay liberationists. You could get locked up for being gay in those days, by both psychiatrists and cops. It's about as 'materialist' a politics as you could fucking get.
Foucault worked with prison activists and the anti-psychiatry movement. As for ppl who think those are trivial 'neoliberal', 'identity politics' concerns: I see you.
